questions.text: Which of these is not true regarding Laryngeal mask airway?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) More Tooth and Laryngeal Trauma

 

Option D. One of the advantages of the LMA is that it typically causes less tooth and laryngeal trauma compared to endotracheal tubes, which require direct laryngoscopy and can cause more mechanical trauma during insertion.

 

Explanation:

 

The Laryngeal Mask Airway (LMA) is a supraglottic airway device placed with its tip in the hypopharynx.

 

Option A. Less Invasive: This is true. The LMA is considered less invasive than endotracheal intubation because it does not enter the trachea and is placed in the hypopharynx.

 

Option B. Better Hemodynamic Stability: This is often true as well. Insertion of an LMA is usually associated with less hemodynamic stimulation compared to endotracheal intubation.

 

Option C. Very Useful in Difficult Intubations: This is true, especially for certain types of LMAs designed for difficult airways, like the Fastrach LMA.

 

The answer provided, Option D, is correct. The LMA is known for causing less, not more, tooth and laryngeal trauma compared to endotracheal intubation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Laryngeal Mask Airway is known for being less invasive with a reduced risk of causing tooth and laryngeal trauma, offering better hemodynamic stability during insertion, and serving as a useful tool in managing difficult airways.

 

 

 

Ref: Millers Anesthesia 8th edition page 1662

choices.text: Operating Room Cart

questions.text: Identify the instruments given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Crash Cart

 

Option A. A crash cart contains emergency medical supplies and medication that are used in cardiac arrest.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Airway Cart: An airway cart is equipped with various sizes of laryngoscope blades, endotracheal tubes, masks, laryngeal mask airways, and possibly also advanced equipment like flexible fiberoptic intubation tools. The cart in the image is consistent with the equipment one would expect in an airway cart.

 

Option C. Operating Room Cart: While an operating room cart may contain a variety of surgical instruments and supplies, the specific collection of airway equipment seen here is more specialized than what would be found in a general operating room cart.

 

Option D. Intubation Cart: An intubation cart would contain equipment specifically for intubation, and while this could be another name for an airway cart, the term "airway cart" is more inclusive, covering a broader range of airway management tools, not just those for intubation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Components of a Crash Cart:

 

  • Medications

 

Medications are usually kept in the top drawer of most crash carts

 

  • Intubation

 

Many crash carts will also include most of the materials necessary to perform intubation.These may be contained in the third or fourth drawers depending on the setup of the particular crash cart.

 

  • Intravenous lines

 

It is usually the case that the equipment necessary to start an IV is in a separate drawer from materials needed to maintain an IV, such as the fluids in the tubing.

 

  • Procedure drawer

 

The bottom drawer on crash carts is usually devoted to keeping prepackaged kits available for various urgent and emergent procedures (or it is where the IV solutions are kept).

 

 

Ref: https://www.aclsmedicaltraining.com/crash-carts/

questions.text: In which of these patients is Rapid Sequence Intubation not indicated?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anxious Patients

 

Option C. Anxiety alone is not an indication for RSI. While anxious patients may require a different approach to induction and securing the airway, the presence of anxiety does not increase the risk of aspiration.

 

Explanation:

 

Rapid Sequence Intubation (RSI) is a technique used to secure the airway rapidly in situations where there is a High risk of Aspiration.

 

Option A. Pregnancy: RSI is indicated in pregnancy, particularly during the second and third trimesters, due to the increased risk of aspiration caused by delayed gastric emptying and the upward pressure of the gravid uterus on the stomach.

 

Option B. Presence of Nasogastric Tube: Although the presence of a nasogastric tube might suggest recent feeding or an obstructed stomach, RSI is still indicated because of the potential risk of regurgitation and aspiration.

 

Option D. Diabetic Gastroparesis: Diabetic patients with gastroparesis have delayed gastric emptying, which puts them at a higher risk for aspiration. RSI is indicated in these patients to minimize this risk during the induction of anesthesia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rapid Sequence Intubation is indicated in situations where there is an increased risk of aspiration, such as in patients with a full stomach, pregnancy, presence of a nasogastric tube, morbid obesity, and conditions like diabetic gastroparesis. It is not indicated solely based on patient anxiety.

 

 

 

Ref: Millers Anesthesia 9th edition page 1382.

questions.text:
Arrange the steps of Rapid sequence induction in the correct order?

 

  1. Pre-oxygenation with 100% 02
  2. IV Succinylcholine
  3. Administration of rapidly acting IV induction agent
  4. Sellick's manoeuvre (cricoid pressure) by assistant
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 4, 3, 2

 

Explanation:

 

Steps of Rapid Sequence Induction:

 

  1. Pre-oxygenation with 100% 02
  2. Sellick's manoeuvre (cricoid pressure) by assistant
  3. Administration of rapidly acting IV induction agent
  4. IV Succinylcholine
  5. Do NOT ventilate patient
  6. Direct laryngoscopy and intubation
  7. Confirm endotracheal tube placement
  8. Remove cricoid pressure
     

 

Educational Objective 

 

The accurate sequence of RSI is pre-oxygenation with 100% O2, application of Sellick's maneuver (cricoid pressure), administration of a rapidly acting IV induction agent, followed by IV succinylcholine.

 

Ref: Miller's Anesthesia 9th edition Page no. 1382

choices.text: Tumour in the Right Lung
Coronary Artery Bypass Graft

questions.text: Which of these is not an indication of the use of the endotracheal tube shown in the picture below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Coronary Artery Bypass Graft

 

The tube shown in the picture is a Double Lumen Tube used for one lung ventilation in Thoracic surgery.

 

Option D. For CABG, one-lung ventilation is not typically required. The surgery is performed on the heart, and standard endotracheal intubation is usually sufficient.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bronchopleural Fistula: This condition can benefit from a double-lumen tube, as it allows ventilation of one lung while the other lung or the fistula is isolated or treated.

 

Option B. Tumour in the Right Lung: A double-lumen tube would be indicated here to allow for the collapse of the affected lung to facilitate surgical access and treatment.

 

Option C. VATS Esophagectomy: During Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery (VATS) for esophagectomy, a double-lumen tube allows for one-lung ventilation, which can provide a better surgical field by deflating the lung on the side of the surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The double-lumen endotracheal tube is used for procedures requiring one-lung ventilation, such as surgeries for bronchopleural fistula, lung tumors, and certain thoracoscopic procedures. It is not indicated for procedures like coronary artery bypass grafting, where one-lung ventilation is not necessary.

 

 

Ref: Principles and practice of anaesthesia for Thoracic surgery

choices.text: Ambulatory Manual Breathing Unit
Artificial Mechanical Breathing Unit
Artificial Manual Breathing Unit
Artificial Mechanical Breathing Unit

questions.text: What is the complete name of this device?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Artificial Manual Breathing Unit

 

Explanation:

 

The device shown in the image is known as a Bag Valve Mask (BVM), which is a hand-held device commonly used to provide positive pressure ventilation to patients who are not breathing or not breathing adequately. The device is also known colloquially as an “AMBU bag,” which stands for “Artificial Manual Breathing Unit.” Here is an explanation of each component labelled in the image:

 

  • Self-inflating Bag: This component allows the bag to reinflate after being squeezed, without requiring a gas supply. It fills with air or oxygen from an attached reservoir or oxygen supply.
  • Expiratory Valve: This allows the exhaled gas to escape the system so that it doesn’t re-enter the patient’s lungs.
  • PEEP Valve: Stands for Positive End-Expiratory Pressure valve, which maintains a small amount of pressure in the lungs to keep the alveoli open at the end of exhalation.
  • Face Mask: Fits over the patient’s nose and mouth to deliver breaths directly into the lungs.
  • Pop-off Valve: A safety feature that prevents the delivery of excessively high pressures which could damage the patient’s lungs.
  • Oxygen Inlet & Tubing: Connects the bag to an oxygen supply to deliver oxygen-enriched air to the patient.
  • Reservoir Bag: Allows a reservoir of oxygen to be available for the patient to ensure the highest possible concentration of oxygen is delivered.
  • Air-inlet One-way Valve & O2 Reservoir Socket: Prevents room air from entering the bag when attached to an oxygen supply and allows for the connection of an oxygen reservoir.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Artificial Manual Breathing Unit (AMBU bag), is a critical device used in emergency medicine and anesthesia for providing ventilation to patients who are not breathing adequately on their own. The device features a self-inflating bag, face mask, oxygen reservoir, and various valves to ensure effective and safe delivery of oxygen to the patient.

 

 

Ref: Understanding anesthetic equipment and procedures 5th edition page 228

choices.text: Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia
Patients with Chest Trauma
All of the Above

questions.text: In which of the following situations will you avoid the below procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

 

Optional A. In this condition, abdominal contents may herniate into the thoracic cavity, compromising lung function. Positive pressure ventilation can exacerbate this by increasing intra-abdominal pressure and further displacing abdominal contents into the chest, worsening respiratory distress. Therefore, it is typically avoided.

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s evaluate each option:

 

Option B. Obese Patients: While BVM ventilation can be more challenging in obese patients due to anatomical considerations, it is not contraindicated. Appropriate modifications, like the ramp position, can be made to facilitate ventilation.

 

Option C. Patients with Chest Trauma: BVM ventilation is not necessarily contraindicated in chest trauma. It can be essential for providing life-saving ventilation, although care must be taken to avoid exacerbating certain injuries such as a tension pneumothorax.

 

Option D. All of the Above: All of the above is not the correct choice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BVM ventilation should be avoided in patients with congenital diaphragmatic hernia due to the risk of worsening respiratory distress by increasing intra-abdominal pressure, which can lead to furtherdisplacement of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity.

 

Bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated in:

 

  • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia
  • Severe facial trauma
  • Rapid sequence induction

 

This is because it can increase intragastric pressure and cause aspiration.

 

 

Ref: Millers anesthesia 8th edition page 1659

choices.text: Flexion of Head, Extension of Neck
Flexion of Neck, Extension of Head
Flexion of Head, Flexion of Neck
Extension of Head, Extension of Neck

questions.text: Ideal position for Intubation is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Flexion of Neck, Extension of Head

 

Option B. Known as the 'Sniffing Position', this involves flexion at the lower cervical spine and extension at the atlanto-occipital joint, aligning the oral, pharyngeal, and laryngeal axes, which is ideal for intubation.

The ideal position for intubation is to align the pharyngeal and laryngeal axes and is called The Sniffing Position.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Flexion of Head, Extension of Neck: This position would not align the axes appropriately for intubation.

 

Option C. Flexion of Head, Flexion of Neck: Both flexions would make it more difficult to align the axes and visualize the vocal cords.

 

Option D. Extension of Head, Extension of Neck: This would misalign the axes, making intubation more difficult.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 'Sniffing Position', which involves flexion of the neck and extension of the head (modified Chevalier Jackson position), is the ideal position for endotracheal intubation. This position aligns the pharyngeal and laryngeal axes to facilitate direct laryngoscopy and intubation.

 

 

Ref: Millers Anesthesia 9th edition pg 1393

questions.text: In which of these situations is nasotracheal intubation contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fracture base of skull

 

Option C. This is a contraindication for nasotracheal intubation. If the base of the skull is fractured, passing a tube through the nasal passages could potentially enter the cranial cavity due to the disruption of the normal anatomical barriers, leading to severe complications.

 

Explanation:

 

NTI Nasotracheal Intubation

 

Option A. Fracture Mandible: While Nasotracheal Intubation could be considered in cases of mandibular fracture, especially if oral access is impeded, it is not absolutely contraindicated. However, care must be taken due to potential complications related to the fracture.

 

Option B. Trismus: Nasotracheal Intubation is often used in this situation because it bypasses the need to open the mouth.

 

Option D. Intraoral Surgery: Nasotracheal Intubation is often indicated for intraoral surgeries as it allows the surgical field to remain clear and unobstructed.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

 

Ref: Miller's Anesthesia 9th edition Page no. 1666

questions.text: Which of these Mapleson circuit is the best for spontaneous ventilation in adults?
questions.solution:
Ans. C.  A>D>C>B

 

(Mnemonic - All Dogs Can Bite)

 

  • To prevent rebreathing a fresh gas flow equal to minute ventilation is important.
  • In all Mapleson circuits, rebreathing of carbon dioxide is prevented by an adequate fresh gas flow and by the presence of adjustable pressure release valve. The exhaled carbon dioxide flows through the outer corrugated tube and out via this valve from where it can be scavenged.
  • The Mapleson A circuit is considered the best for spontaneous ventilation because it requires a fresh gas inflow rate of only 1 times minute ventilation to prevent rebreathing of carbon dioxide.
  • Thus, the Mapleson A design is the most efficient for spontaneous ventilation.
  • Mapleson A is also called Magill’s circuit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For spontaneous ventilation in adults, the Mapleson A circuit (Magill’s circuit) is the most efficient, followed by D, C, and B, in decreasing order of efficiency. This is because Mapleson A requires the lowest fresh gas flow rate to prevent carbon dioxide rebreathing. The mnemonic "All Dogs Can Bite" can be used to remember the order A>D>C>B for their efficiency in preventing rebreathing during spontaneous ventilation.

 

 

Ref: Understanding anesthesia equipment 210-219

choices.text: S and C technique
C and E technique
D and E technique

questions.text: What is the name of this technique of mask ventilation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. C and E technique

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts a technique commonly used in medical settings during bag and mask ventilation.

 

The technique illustrated is known as the "C and E Technique," which is a method employed during Bag-Valve-Mask (BVM) ventilation. This approach is utilized to maintain an open airway and ensure effective ventilation in patients who are not breathing adequately or at all.

 

The "C and E" refers to the hand placement:

 

  • "C" represents the shape formed by the thumb and index finger, which are placed on the mask to create an airtight seal against the patient's face.
  • "E" signifies the remaining fingers (middle, ring, and little fingers) that are positioned under the mandible (jawbone) to lift and thrust the jaw forward. This maneuver helps in keeping the airway open by preventing the tongue from occluding the oropharynx.
  • The thumb and index fingers pressing against the mask while the other fingers lift the jaw forms the distinctive "C" and "E" shapes, hence the name. The jaw thrust achieved by the "E" fingers is vital as it elevates the tongue off the back wall of the throat, reducing airway obstruction and facilitating better airflow during artificial ventilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The technique depicted in the image is known as the 'C and E technique' for mask ventilation during bag-valve-mask (BVM) ventilation. This technique involves forming a 'C' shape with the thumb and index finger to create an airtight mask seal and using the remaining fingers to lift and thrust the jaw forward ('E' shape) to maintain an open airway, preventing tongue obstruction during artificial ventilation.

 

 

Ref: Understanding Anesthetic equipment and procedures 5th edition page 446

choices.text: Face Mask with Reservoir

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with COVID pneumonia is admitted to the casualty with respiratory distress and spo2 85% on room air. Maximum oxygen concentration can be delivered by which oxygen delivery device?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Face Mask with Reservoir

 

Option D. Reservoir Face Mask:

 

  • It is a variable performance device. These masks provide a higher FiO2 as there is a reservoir bag attached to the face mask. Oxygen flows directly into the reservoir bag. The patient inhales oxygen preferentially from the reservoir. FiO2 varies depending on mask fit, capacity of reservoir bag, Oxygen flow rates and patient’s inspiratory flow.

 

Partial rebreathing mask is a simple mask with a reservoir bag. At a flow of 6–10 L/min the system can provide 40–70% oxygen. Non-rebreathing masks are similar to partial rebreathing masks but do not permit the mixing of exhaled gases with the fresh gas supply. There should be a minimum flow of 10 L/min. The delivered FiO2 of this system is 75–90% at flow rates of 12–15 L/m.

 

Explanation:

 

Oxygen Therapy Devices

 

  • Supplemental Oxygen can be supplied by a variety of devices.

 

Option A. Venturi Mask:

 

  • It is the high flow, fixed performance device. An air-entrainment mask contains a jet orifice and air entrainment ports and is designed to fit over the patient’s nose and mouth. The oxygen is supplied to the mask through narrow bore oxygen tubing under pressure. When oxygen under pressure is forced through a small jet orifice entering the mask, a negative pressure is created, which caused room air to be entrained into the mask through the apertures in the Venturi barrel. The resultant air-oxygen mixture containing the prescribed O2 concentration flows into the face piece for patient breathing. Due to the high-flow rates, the excess gas flushes out the expired CO2 through the holes on the sides of the mask. As a result, of this there is no rebreathing or no increase in dead space. When oxygen flow is increased, more air is entrained, to maintain a constant oxygen concentration. The system is called HAFOE (High Air Flow with Oxygen Enrichment). Variations in the size of the entrainment ports determine the FiO2 and variation in the oxygen flow rate determines the total flow delivered. The entrainment mechanism is based on the principles described by Bernoulli. The FiO2 can be precisely controlled from 0.24-0.6. (24–60%) at high-flow rates by simply exchanging the interchangeable jet nozzles and adjusting the oxygen flow rate.
     

Flow rate and FiO2 with Venturi Mask

 

 

Option B. Nasal Cannula:
 

  • Are low flow variable performance devices with no capacity. They consist of two soft prongs that arise from oxygen supply tubing. The prongs are inserted into the patient’s anterior nares, and the tubing is secured to the patient’s face by an adjustable strap. Oxygen is delivered through the cannula, but at low flow rates between 0.5–5.0 L/min. The patient’s nasopharynx acts as an anatomic reservoir. When the patient inspires, the oxygen is diluted with room air. The degree of dilution depends on the patient’s inspiratory flows. The resulting FiO2 depends on the flow rate of oxygen, patient’s minute ventilation and inspiratory flow and the volume of the nasopharynx. The FiO2 cannot therefore be precisely controlled, but the maximal tracheal FiO2 is not likely to exceed 0.4 (40%).
  • So, the disadvantage of using nasal cannula is it delivers an unpredictable FiO2 with a maximum estimated FiO2 of 0.4.

 

Option C. Face Mask:
 

  • Simple face mask is a low flow variable performance device with small capacity. They are plastic reservoirs designed to fit the patients’ nose and mouth. An elastic strap is used to secure the mask around the patient’s head.
  • Simple oxygen mask can provide 35–60% FiO2, at flow rates 5–10 L/Min. Like nasal cannula face mask also delivers an unpredictable FiO2 with not more than FiO2 of 0.6.

 

Educational Objective:-

 

 

 

Ref: Understanding Anesthetic Equipment and Procedures, Dwarkadas K Baheti Pg 233-238

choices.text: Cervical Spine Injury
Head and Neck Surgery

questions.text: Identify the condition in which this manoeuvre is used?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Cervical Spine Injury

 

Option C. This is the correct answer. MILS is used during airway management in patients with suspected or known cervical spine injuries to prevent additional spinal cord damage.

 

Explanation:

 

The maneuver described is Manual In-Line Stabilization (MILS), which is specifically used in the context of a suspected cervical spine injury.

 

The primary goal of MILS is to maintain the cervical spine in a neutral alignment during airway manipulation, which could otherwise cause secondary injury to the spinal cord. After the airway is secured, MILS is replaced with more definitive immobilization devices like a cervical collar, lateral blocks, sandbags, and head and chin straps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MANUAL IN-LINE STABILISATION (MILS)

 

MILS is performed by an assistant during airway management to maintain a neutral position and prevent inadvertent movement of the head and neck to provide airway management with cervical spine stabilization, by either:

 

  • Crouching beside the intubator with hands placed on the patient’s mastoid processes or cradling the occiput
  • Standing beside the patient in front of the intubator with hands placed on the sides of the patient’s head and forearms resting on the patient’s chest
  • Traction must not be applied
  • Note that there is no universal definition of neutral position

 

MILS is replaced by a cervical collar, lateral blocks/sandbags, and head and chin straps once the airway is secure.

 

 

Ref: https://litfl.com/airway-and-cervical-spine-injury/

choices.text: It is used in Children.
It can be used for Spontaneous as well as Controlled Ventilation.
It is used for patients weighing less than 20 kg.
All of the above statements are correct.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about the circuit given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All of the above statements are correct.

 

Option D. Since all the previous statements are correct, this statement is also correct.

 

Explanation:

 

Mapleson F or Jackson Rees’ circuit is the circuit of choice for paediatrics in both spontaneous and controlled ventilation.

 

It is used in neonates, infants, and paediatric patients less than 20 kg in weight or less than 5 years of age.

 

Option A. It is used in children: This is correct. The Mapleson F circuit is indeed commonly used in pediatric anesthesia due to its simplicity and effectiveness for smaller patients.

 

Option B. It can be used for spontaneous as well as controlled ventilation: This is also correct. The Mapleson F circuit can be used for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation, with the clinician either allowing the child to breathe on their own or manually ventilating with the attached bag.

 

Option C. It is used for patients weighing less than 20 kg: This statement is correct as well. The Mapleson F circuit is suitable for neonates, infants, and pediatric patients typically less than 20 kg or those less than 5 years of age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mapleson F or Jackson Rees’ circuit is designed for pediatric patients, suitable for those weighing less than 20 kg, and can be used for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation. Understanding the specific requirements of fresh gas flow and the functioning of this circuit is essential for safe pediatric anesthesia practice.

 

  • The flows required to prevent rebreathing are 2.5-3.0 times the minute volume during spontaneous ventilation and 1.5 to 2 times a minute volume during controlled ventilation.

 

 

Ref: Millers Anaesthesia 9th edition page 612

choices.text: For Intubation in an Anticipated Difficult Airway
Guide Placement of Double Lumen Tube
Suction of Blood from the Airways

questions.text: Identify the use of the equipment shown below in the picture?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the Above

 

Option D. Since the bronchoscope can be used for all the above-mentioned purposes, this option is the correct answer.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. For Intubation in an Anticipated Difficult Airway: A flexible fiberoptic bronchoscope is often used to navigate and visualize the airway in cases where difficult intubation is anticipated, such as with abnormal airway anatomy.

 

Option B. Guide Placement of Double Lumen Tube: In thoracic surgery requiring lung isolation, a double-lumen endotracheal tube is used, and a fiberoptic bronchoscope is often employed to confirm proper placement and position of the tube.

 

Option C. Suction of Blood from the Airways: While primarily used for visualization, a bronchoscope can also assist in the suctioning of blood or secretions from the airway when necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A flexible fiberoptic bronchoscope and understand its multifunctional use in airway management, including aiding difficult intubations, guiding the placement of double-lumen tubes, and clearing the airways of obstructions such as blood or secretions.

 

 

Ref: Understanding anaesthetic equipment and procedures 5th edition page 242

questions.text: Identify the part marked in the endotracheal tube?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Murphys eye

 

The part of the endotracheal tube indicated by the arrows in the image is known as Murphy's eye.

 

This is a hole on the side of the distal end of the tube. It is designed to provide an alternative pathway for airflow in case the main lumen of the tube becomes obstructed, thus ensuring continuous ventilation.

 

Murphys Eye. This feature is a safety mechanism to reduce the risk of complete airway obstruction if the end of the tube becomes occluded by mucus, blood, or the tracheal wall.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cuff: The cuff is a balloon-like structure near the end of the tube, which is inflated to secure the tube within the trachea and prevent air from leaking around the tube.

 

Option B. Radiological Mark: This is typically a line or series of markings along the length of the tube that can be seen on an X-ray to help determine the position of the tube within the trachea.

 

Option D. Distal End: The distal end is the tip of the endotracheal tube that enters the trachea, but it is not what is being indicated by the arrows in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Murphy's eye on an endotracheal tube as a secondary opening that provides an alternative path for ventilation, which is crucial if the main lumen becomes blocked.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhails Clinical Anesthesiology 5th edition page no. 321

choices.text: One Hand Technique
Two Hand Technique

questions.text: What is the name of this technique of bag and mask ventilation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Two-Person Technique

 

Option D. Two-Person Technique requires Two Rescuers: One to hold the mask with both hands to ensure a tight seal, and the other to squeeze the bag to deliver breaths. This allows for optimal airway management and is generally more effective than the one-person method.

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s evaluate each option:

 

Option A. One-Hand Technique refers to the method where a single hand of the rescuer is used to hold the mask on the patient’s face. This is challenging and may not provide an adequate seal for effective ventilation.

 

Option B. Two-Hand Technique describes the use of both hands of a single rescuer to hold the mask on the patient’s face. While this can provide a better seal than the one-hand technique, it is still often less effective than having two rescuers.

 

Option C. One-Person Technique involves a single rescuer performing all tasks of BVM ventilation: holding the mask, maintaining the airway, and squeezing the bag. This can be difficult and less effective, especially in an unresponsive patient or when a tight seal is hard to maintain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The two-person technique for BVM ventilation, utilizes one person to hold the mask with both hands for a tight seal and another to compress the bag and it is the preferred and more effective method for providing assisted ventilation in a clinical setting.

 

 

Ref: https://www.msdmanuals.com/en-in/professional/critical-care-medicine/how-to-do-basic-airway-procedures/how-to-do-bag-valve-mask-bvm-ventilation

questions.text: Identify this position used for intubation in obese patients?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) RAMP Position

 

The image in the picture is RAMP position used to facilitate Intubation, particularly in Obese Patients.

 

Option B. This is an elevated Head and Upper Body Position, where the patient is placed on an incline or ramped by using blankets or pillows under the upper back, shoulders, and head. The goal is to align the External Auditory Meatus with the Sternal Notch, which can improve the Laryngoscopic view in Obese Patients.

 

Explanation:

 

Lets evaluate each option:

 

Option A. Sniffing Position: This is a traditional position for intubation where the patient's head is tilted back, and the neck is flexed. It is used to align the oral, pharyngeal, and laryngeal axes to improve the view of the glottis during laryngoscopy.

Option C. Rose Position: This position is used for Tonsillectomy.

 

Option D. Barking Dog Position: This is not a standard term used in airway management for intubation. It may be confused with the 'prone' or 'knee-chest' position used for different medical procedures or assessments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The RAMP Position is an effective technique for optimizing airway alignment during intubation in obese patients. This position improves the laryngoscopic view and potentially reduces the difficulty of the procedure.

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhails anaesthesiology 5th edition Chapter 19 airway management

questions.text: Preoxygenation involves holding a mask with 100% oxygen for ----- minutes to increase the oxygen reserve in the lungs?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 3 minutes

 

Option B. This is the commonly recommended duration for preoxygenation with 100% oxygen to fill the Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) of the lungs with oxygen, displacing nitrogen and providing a buffer against desaturation during apnea.

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s evaluate each option:

 

Option A. 2 minutes: This duration may be used in Rapid Sequence Induction (RSI) but typically may not fully saturate the lungs with oxygen.

 

Option C. 5 minutes: While longer preoxygenation can be beneficial, 3 minutes is generally sufficient to increase the oxygen reserve in the lungs for healthy adults.

 

Option D. 10 minutes: This duration is longer than typically recommended for standard preoxygenation and may be unnecessary in most situations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen for 3 minutes before intubation increases the oxygen reserve in the lungs, providing a margin of safety against hypoxemia during periods of apnea by replacing nitrogen in the lungs with oxygen (Denitrogenation).

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Anesthesiology 5th edition Chapter 19 airway management

questions.text: Using a cuff pressure manometer shown in the image below, it is recommended that the endotracheal cuff pressure should be maintained below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 20-30 cm H2O

 

Option B. This is the recommended range of cuff pressure for most adult patients. It is high enough to maintain a proper seal and prevent aspiration but low enough to reduce the risk of tracheal mucosal ischemia and injury.

 

Explanation:

 

A Cuff Pressure Manometer is a device used to measure the pressure within the cuff of an Endo Tracheal Tube (ETT) when it is inflated within a patient's trachea. The correct cuff pressure is important to ensure there is a seal within the trachea to prevent aspiration and to minimize the risk of tracheal injury.

 

Option A. 10-20 cm H2O: This range may be too low for most adult patients to maintain an adequate seal of the endotracheal tube within the trachea, potentially leading to air leaks and aspiration.

 

Option C. 30-40 cm H2O: This pressure range is higher than recommended and may increase the risk of tracheal damage due to ischemia of the tracheal mucosa caused by excessive pressure on the tracheal walls.

 

Option D. < 40 cm H2O: Any pressure below 40 cm H2O might be safe, but this range is not specific enough to ensure both a good seal and minimal risk of tracheal damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When using a cuff pressure manometer, the endotracheal cuff pressure should be maintained within the range of 20-30 cm H2O to ensure an adequate tracheal seal while minimizing the risk of tracheal mucosal injury.

 

 

Ref: Dorsch and Dorsch understanding anesthesia equipment 5th edition, page 776

choices.text: From Tragus of Ear to Corner of Mouth
From Tragus of Ear to Ala of Nose
From Tragus of Ear to Tip of Nose
From Tragus of Ear to Bridge of Nose

questions.text: How do you measure the size of the below instrument?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. From Tragus of Ear to Ala of Nose

 

The image shown above is of a nasopharyngeal airway (NPA)

 

Option B. This is the correct method for measuring an NPA. It ensures that the airway's length is sufficient to reach from the nostril to the posterior pharynx without causing trauma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. From Tragus of Ear to Corner of Mouth: This method is not typically used for sizing an NPA; it is more relevant for oropharyngeal airways.

 

Option C. From Tragus of Ear to Tip of Nose: This is not the standard measurement for an NPA as it may not provide the accurate length needed for proper placement.

 

Option D. From Tragus of Ear to Bridge of Nose: This measurement is not used for NPAs and might result in an incorrect estimation of the required length.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To accurately measure a nasopharyngeal airway by determining the correct size from the tragus of the ear to the ala of the nose. This ensures the airway is long enough to bypass the tongue and facilitate breathing, without being so long that it causes trauma to the airway structures.

 

Contraindications of Nasopharyngeal Airway:

A) Fracture base of skull

B) Bleeding

 

Ref: Millers anesthesia 8th edition page 1661

choices.text: From Tragus of Ear to Corner of Mouth
From Corner of Mouth to Angle of Mandible
From Tragus of Ear to Angle of Mandible
From Tragus of Ear to Central Incisors

questions.text: How do you measure the size of the below instrument?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. From Tragus of Ear to Corner of Mouth

 

The image provided shows an Oro Pharyngeal Airway (OPA), a device used to maintain a patent airway by preventing the tongue from covering the epiglottis and obstructing the airway. Here's how you measure the size of an OPA:

 

 

Option A. This is the correct method to measure an OPA. It ensures that the airway extends past the tongue to keep the airway open without being so long as to cause trauma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. From Corner of Mouth to Angle of Mandible: This is not a standard method for measuring an OPA. The length from the corner of the mouth to the angle of the mandible might not provide the appropriate length for the airway device.

 

Option C. From Tragus of Ear to Angle of Mandible: This measurement can be used as an alternative to the tragus to the corner of the mouth, especially if the mouth cannot be opened.

 

Option D. From Tragus of Ear to Central Incisors: This measurement is not used for sizing an OPA and would likely result in an inappropriate length.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An oropharyngeal airway is sized by measuring from the tragus of the ear to the corner of the mouth of the patient. This sizing ensures the device is long enough to bypass the tongue to maintain airway patency without extending so far as to cause discomfort or injury to the larynx.

 

 

Ref: Understanding anesthetic equipment and procedures 5th edition page 216

choices.text: Peak Pressure on Ventilator

questions.text: The correct placement of a Laryngeal Mask Airway can be confirmed by which monitor?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Capnography

 

Option C. Capnography measures the concentration of carbon dioxide in exhaled air and provides real-time feedback on ventilation, confirming that the LMA is correctly placed over the glottic opening if a normal capnography waveform is observed.

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s evaluate each option:

 

Option A. Peak Pressure on Ventilator: While peak pressures may change with correct or incorrect placement, they are not a definitive method for confirming LMA placement.

 

Option B. X-Ray: While an X-ray can confirm the placement of various tubes, it is not the first-line method for confirming LMA placement.

 

Option D. Auscultation: While auscultation of breath sounds can suggest correct placement, it cannot definitively confirm it as breath sounds may be transmitted even if the LMA is not optimally positioned.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gold standard for confirming the correct placement of a Laryngeal Mask Airway is capnography, as it provides real-time verification that exhaled gases are passing through the device, indicating correct placement over the glottic opening.

 

 

Ref: Millers Anaesthesia 8th ED pg 1662

questions.text: Identify the equipment used for intubation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Millers Laryngoscope

 

Option C. This is a straight-bladed laryngoscope designedto go under the epiglottis and directly lift it for visualization of the vocal cords. It is especially useful in pediatric patients due to their relatively larger and floppier epiglottis.

Note - Miller`s Laryngoscope is introduced from middle of oral Cavity

Explanation:

 

Option A. Macintosh Laryngoscope: This laryngoscope has a curved blade and is designed to be placed in the vallecula, the space at the base of the tongue, to indirectly lift the epiglottis and expose the vocal cords. It is used in adults and Blade is introduced into oral cavity from one corner of mouth

 

 

Option B. McCoy Laryngoscope: The McCoy blade is a modification of the Macintosh with a hinge on the distal end of the blade. When the handle is squeezed, the tip of the blade lifts, which can help lift the epiglottis directly.

 

 

Option D. Matador's Laryngoscope: This is not a recognized type of laryngoscope blade in common medical practice.

 

Given the description and the answer provided, the image likely depicts a Miller Laryngoscope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Miller laryngoscope, characterized by its straight blade with an upward curve at the distal end, which is specifically designed to directly lift the epiglottis for clear visualization during intubation procedures.

 

 

Ref: Understanding anesthetic equipment and procedures 5th edition page 148

questions.text: Identify this instrument?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. McCoy Laryngoscope

 

Option B. Recognizable by its hinged tip that can be flexed upwards when a lever on the handle is activated. This feature is particularly useful in difficult airway situations and can minimize cervical spine movement.

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s evaluate each option:

 

Option A. Macintosh Laryngoscope: This type of laryngoscope has a curved blade and is designed to be placed into the vallecula, indirectly lifting the epiglottis to visualize the vocal cords. Mcintosh Laryngoscope is used in adults and Blade is introduced into oral cavity from one corner of mouth

 

Option C. Miller's Laryngoscope: This laryngoscope has a straight blade and is typically used to lift the epiglottis directly, providing a clear view of the vocal cords, especially in pediatric patients. It is introduced from middle of oral Cavity.

 

Option D. The Polio Blade Laryngoscope is a specialized intubation device designed with a curved blade that facilitates the visualisation of the vocal cords without the need for aligning the oral, pharyngeal, and laryngeal axes, often used in patients with suspected cervical spine injuries.

 

Given the distinct feature of a hinged tip that can be controlled by a lever on the handle, the instrument in the image is identified as a McCoy Laryngoscope, corresponding to Option B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

McCoy laryngoscope, which features a flexible tip blade with a lever-controlled hinge, allowing for the flexion of the distal end to aid in intubation, particularly useful in patients with difficult airways or those requiring minimal cervical spine manipulation.

 

 

Ref: Understanding anesthetic equipment and procedures 5th edition page 151

questions.text: What is the appropriate size LMA for a child weighing 16 kilograms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Size 2

 

LMA contains a shaft and an oval-shaped inflatable cuff. It is to be inserted along the hard palate until some resistance is met and then inflate the cuff. It forms a seal around periglottic tissue (sits above the vocal cord in the hypopharynx)

Advantages: A) Use for short Procedures B) For Daycare Anaesthesia

Disadvantages: A) Can't prevent aspiration B) Can cause Laryngospasm

Contraindications: LMA is contra-indicated in conditions where there are high chances of Aspiration (Hiatal hernia, Pregnancy)

M/C complication of LMA is short-throat.

 

Ref: Dorsch and Dorsch Understanding anaesthetic equipment and procedures 5th edition page 683-687

choices.text: Failure to Maintain or Protect the Airway.
Failure of Ventilation or Oxygenation.
Patient's anticipated Clinical Course and likelihood of Deterioration.
All of the Above.

questions.text: Which of these essential criteria decide if intubation is necessary in the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All of the Above.

 

Option D. All of the above: Since all these factors are critical considerations for endotracheal intubation, this is the correct answer.

 

Explanation:

 

The essential criteria for deciding if intubation is necessary in a patient include:

 

Option A. Failure to Maintain or Protect the Airway: This can occur in cases of trauma, neurological impairment, or other conditions that compromise airway reflexes.

 

Option B. Failure of Ventilation or Oxygenation: Indications include conditions like acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), severe asthma, or other causes of respiratory failure.

 

Option C. Patient's anticipated Clinical Course and likelihood of Deterioration: This involves clinical judgment about the patient's potential for worsening and the need for advanced airway management to prevent critical decompensation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The decision to intubate is based on the necessity to maintain or protect the airway, ensure adequate ventilation or oxygenation, and anticipate the patient’s clinical course to preempt deterioration, requiring a multifaceted assessment of the patient's condition.

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s anaesthesiology 5th edition

questions.text: Which of these Laryngeal mask airways is most preferred for use in daycare anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Proseal LMA

 

Option D. This is a second-generation, re-usable LMA that has an integrated bite block, a drainage tube for gastric secretions, and a dual seal airway to reduce the risk of aspiration. It can be used in various surgical positions, which makes it versatile for use in different types of procedures, including in daycare settings.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Supreme LMA: This is a single-use, second-generation LMA with an integrated bite block and a gastric access channel, but it is not typically noted for its reusability.

 

 

 

Option B. Fastrach LMA: Also known as the intubating LMA or ILMA, this is specifically designed to facilitate blind intubation and is not primarily used for daycare anesthesia.

 

 

Option C. I-Gel LMA: This is a single-use, non-inflatable LMA made from a thermoplastic elastomer, which molds itself to the hypopharynx anatomy. While it is quick and easy to insert, it's not necessarily the most preferred for daycare anesthesia.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Proseal LMA is often the preferred choice for daycare anesthesia due to its reusable nature, effective seal, integrated bite block, and gastric access, which collectively enhance safety and versatility across various surgical procedures and patient positions.

 

 

Ref: Understanding anesthetic equipment and procedures 5th edition page 474

questions.text: Which of these Laryngeal mask airways is most preferred in an anticipated difficult intubation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Fastrach LMA

 

Option B. Often referred to as the Intubating LMA or ILMA, this LMA is specifically designed to assist in the intubation of patients with difficult airways. It has a rigid handle and an epiglottis elevator, which helps guide an endotracheal tube into the larynx through the LMA.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Among the LMAs in the options:

 

Option A. Supreme LMA: A single-use LMA with an integrated bite block and gastric access channel, suitable for a variety of procedures but not specifically designed for difficult airway management.

 

Option C. I-Gel LMA: This is a single-use LMA with a non-inflatable cuff and is known for its ease of insertion. Although it is not specifically designed for difficult airway management, its non-inflatable cuff can provide a reliable airway seal.

 

Option D. Proseal LMA: While it provides a good seal and allows for gastric access, the Proseal LMA is not specifically designed for facilitating intubation in the event of a difficult airway.

 

Therefore, the answer is Option B, the Fastrach LMA, due to its design advantages for facilitating endotracheal intubation through the device in patients with anticipated difficult airways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The LMA Fastrach, with its rigid handle and epiglottis elevator, is designed for use in anticipated difficult intubations, allowing for the passage of an endotracheal tube through the LMA into the larynx, representing a significant advantage over other LMA designs in such scenarios.

 

 

Ref: Understanding anesthetic equipment and procedures 5th edition page 474

choices.text: LMA is not Good due to Risk of Aspiration
LMA can cause Sore Throat
LMA can cause Pressure Necrosis of Vocal Cords
LMA can commonly cause Lingual Nerve Palsy

questions.text: A 23-year-old singer is posted for a sebaceous cyst excision under general anaesthesia. The surgeon requests you if you would use an LMA for the case since it will take only half hour. You deny the surgeons request because?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. LMA can cause Sore Throat

 

Option B. An LMA can cause a sore throat, which might be a consideration for a singer who relies on their voice for their profession. Any irritation or soreness in the throat could potentially impact their ability to perform.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. LMA is not Good due to Risk of Aspiration: While there is a risk of aspiration with LMA use, particularly if the stomach is not empty, it is not the primary reason for avoiding LMA use in a singer, as the risk can be managed with proper patient selection and technique.

 

Option C. LMA can cause Pressure Necrosis of Vocal Cords: This is a potential complication, but it is rare and more commonly associated with endotracheal intubation rather than LMA use.

 

Option D. LMA can commonly cause Lingual Nerve Palsy: This is a rare complication and is not a common occurrence with LMA use.

 

Given these considerations, the most likely reason to avoid using an LMA in a singer undergoing a short procedure like a sebaceous cyst excision is the potential for causing a sore throat, which is option B. This could affect the singer’s performance and is a valid concern, particularly if the performance schedule is tight.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When considering airway management options for a singer undergoing a short surgical procedure, an LMA could be declined due to the risk of causing a sore throat, which can directly impact vocal performance. Although rare, complications like nerve injury and pressure necrosis can also occur and should be weighed against the benefits of using an LMA.

 

 

Ref: Millers Anaesthesia 9th edition page 1390

choices.text: 4 Vital Capacity Breaths with 100% Oxygen
6 Vital Capacity Breaths with 100% Oxygen
8 Vital Capacity Breaths with 100% Oxygen
16 Vital Capacity Breaths with 100% Oxygen

questions.text: An emergency repair of stump blowout of carotid artery is being taken in the operating room. You don’t have 3 minutes to pre-oxygenate the patient as induction has to be very quick. What would be the ideal alternative for waiting 3 minutes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 8 Vital Capacity Breaths with 100% Oxygen

 

Explanation:

 

In an emergency like a Carotid Artery Stump Blowout where rapid induction of anesthesia is required and the standard 3-minute pre-oxygenation is not feasible, an alternative method of Pre-Oxygenation is needed to quickly fill the Lungs with Oxygen and extend the time before Desaturation occurs during Apnea.

 

Methods of Pre-oxygenation:

 

  1. Tidal volume ventilation through Facemask for 3 minutes with 100% oxygen
  2. 8 Vital Capacity breaths over 1 minute achieve adequate Pre-Oxygenation more rapidly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an emergency where standard pre-oxygenation of 3 minutes is not feasible, taking 8 vital capacity breaths of 100% oxygen over 1 minute is an effective alternative to rapidly increase oxygen reserves and delay the onset of hypoxemia during the apnea period of rapid sequence induction.

 

 

Ref: Millers Anaesthesia 9th edition page 1380.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male met with a road traffic accident. He is on the ventilator since a week. A tracheostomy tube is placed as an airway device. The sister has to suction it often as the secretions start blocking the tube. This makes the patient hypoxic every time during the suctioning. How much time is enough to suction a tracheostomy tube?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 15 seconds

 

Option A. This is the correct and recommended duration for suctioning a tracheostomy tube. Suctioning should be quick and efficient to minimize the time the patient is without ventilation and to reduce the risk of hypoxia. Prolonged suctioning can lead to significant drops in oxygen levels.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B, C and D: This duration may be too long, as it can significantly increase the risk of hypoxemia, especially in a patient who is already ventilator dependent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Suctioning of a tracheostomy tube should be performed for no longer than 15 seconds at a time to minimize the risk of hypoxia, with appropriate measures such as pre-oxygenation taken to safeguard the patient's oxygen levels during the procedure.

 

 

Ref: Paul Marino the ICU book 5th edition.

choices.text: Backwards Shift of Larynx
Internal Laryngeal Manoeuvre
Backward - Upward - Rightward Pressure

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with extradural haemorrhage and Glasgow coma scale of 6/15 is being intubated in the ICU. The glottis can’t be seen very well, so the intubating anaesthetist asks for BURP manoeuvre. What is that manoeuvre?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Backward - Upward - Rightward Pressure

 

Option D. This is the correct definition of the BURP maneuver. An assistant applies pressure in a backward, upward, and rightward direction to the thyroid cartilage, which can help improve the view of the glottis during laryngoscopy when the glottic opening is not well visualized.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s evaluate each option:

 

Option A. Backwards Shift of Larynx: This term doesn’t precisely describe the BURP maneuver, which involves more than just a backward shift of the larynx.

 

Option B. Internal Laryngeal Maneuver: This could be mistaken for the BURP maneuver but is more akin to the Sellick maneuver, which involves pressure on the cricoid cartilage to occlude the esophagus during rapid sequence intubation.

 

 

Option C. Jaw Thrust: This maneuver involves lifting the jaw forward without tilting the head or neck and is used to open the airway, not specifically to improve the glottic view during intubation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The BURP maneuver, which entails applying backward, upward, and rightward pressure to the thyroid cartilage, is used to enhance the glottic view during intubation when direct visualization is challenging.

 

 

Ref: Millers Anesthesia 9th edition page 1396.

choices.text: Positive Pressure Ventilation less than 10 cm H2O to prevent Hypoxia.
Positive Pressure Ventilation less than 20 cm H2O to prevent Hypoxia.
Positive Pressure Ventilation less than 30 cm H2O to prevent Hypoxia.
Positive Pressure Ventilation less than 40 cm H2O to prevent Hypoxia.

questions.text: Which of these is true regarding Modified Rapid sequence intubation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Positive Pressure Ventilation less than 20 cm H2O to prevent Hypoxia.

 

Explanation:

 

Modified RSI:

 

Modified Rapid Sequence Intubation (RSI) is an adaptation of the classic RSI technique, which allows for some ventilation between induction and intubation to prevent hypoxemia.

 

  1. Gentle Ventilation: Modified RSI includes the administration of gentle positive pressure ventilation with pressures typically less than 20 cm H2O. This is to reduce the risk of gastric insufflation that could lead to aspiration while providing oxygen to prevent hypoxemia.
  2. Cricoid Pressure: Maintaining cricoid pressure is an important aspect of modified RSI to help prevent passive regurgitation of stomach contents into the pharynx and lower risk of aspiration.
  3. Patient Populations: It is particularly useful for patients at increased risk of desaturation and hypoxemia, such as those who are obese, pregnant, or critically ill, including pediatric patients.
  4. Emergency Situations: Modified RSI is beneficial in emergency situations where there hasn't been adequate time for preoxygenation or when preoxygenation has been ineffective.
  5. Hypoxia Prevention: The primary goal of modified RSI is to prevent hypoxia during the period of apnea after induction of anesthesia and before endotracheal intubation, while still protecting against aspiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In modified rapid sequence intubation, gentle positive pressure ventilation with pressures less than 20 cm H2O is used to mitigate the risk of hypoxia while maintaining cricoid pressure to prevent aspiration, particularly in patients who are at increased risk of rapid desaturation.

 

 

Ref: Millers Anesthesia 9th edition page 1382.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child has been posted for circumcision under general anesthesia. Which size endotracheal tube should be kept ready to intubate this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 4.5 mm.

 

Explanation:

 

Size of an endotracheal tube usually refers to the internal diameter in mm.

 

According to the Penlington formula, size of the endotracheal tube in the paediatric population is calculated by:

 

  • <6 years: 4 + [Age/4)
  • >6 years: 4.5 + [Age/4]

 

By the formula, the appropriate size of the endotracheal tube for this child is 4.5 mm.

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anaesthesiology 5th edition page no. 321,551 and 892.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child has been posted for circumcision under general anesthesia. What should be the depth of insertion of this tube?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 13 cm

 

Explanation:

 

The appropriate length of the endotracheal tube for a 2-year-old child is 13 cm.

 

The formula to estimate endotracheal tube length is: 12 + (Age/2) = Length of tube (in cm)

If the ETT is inserted too deep, it can lead to Endobronchial Intubation. If inserted too shallow, it can lead to Accidental Extubation.

 

An adequately sized tube should be placed with its tip midway between the vocal cords and the carina.

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 5th edition page no. 892.

choices.text: Micro Laryngeal Tube
Double Lumen Tube

questions.text: Identify the endotracheal tube given in the picture below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Flexometallic Tube

 

Option C. Also known as a Reinforced or Armored Endo Tracheal Tube, it has a spiral-bound metal coil embedded within the tube wall to prevent kinking or collapse. The flexibility of the tube makes it a good choice for surgeries where the neck or head may be moved or positioned in a way that could compress a regular endotracheal tube.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Laser Tube: These tubes are designed to be resistant to ignition during laser surgery near the airway. They are typically made of metal or have a metalized external surface.

 

 

Option B. Micro Laryngeal Tube: These are small diameter tubes used during laryngeal surgeries to provide adequate space for the surgeon to work while maintaining airway patency.

 

 

Option D. Double Lumen Tube: This tube has two separate lumens, one for each lung, and is used primarily in thoracic surgery to allow for independent lung ventilation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Flexometallic Endotracheal Tube, which is characterized by its reinforced structure that resists kinking, making it suitable for use in surgeries where the airway might be compromised due to positioning, such as in head and neck surgeries, surgeries performed in the prone position, and neurosurgeries where the patient is in a sitting position.

 

 

Ref: Millers Anesthesia 8th edition page 1666

choices.text: North Pole Tube
South Pole Tube
Double Lumen Tube

questions.text: Identify the endotracheal tube given in the picture below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. North Pole Tube

 

Option A. Also known as the RAE (Ring-Adair-Elwyn) North Pole endotracheal tube, it has a preformed bend that faces toward the patient's forehead or "north pole," which is designed to keep the breathing circuit away from the surgical field during oral or facial surgery.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. South Pole Tube: The RAE South Pole tube has a bend that is directed downward toward the patient's chest or "South Pole," and it is typically used for surgeries where the tube needs to be directed away from the surgical field around the head and neck.

 

Option C. Microlaryngeal Tube: These are smaller diameter tubes used for laryngeal surgeries to provide ventilation while allowing more space for the surgeon to operate.

 

Option D. Double Lumen Tube: This type of tube is used for providing independent ventilation to each lung and is not related to the direction of the tube outside of the patient's body.

 

Given the presence of the preformed bend and the direction it is facing, the correct answer would be Option A, the North Pole tube, assuming the bend is intended to face towards the patient's forehead when in use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The RAE North Pole endotracheal tube, which is designed with a preformed bend to keep the external part of the tube away from the surgical field, particularly useful in oral and facial surgeries.

 

 

Ref: Millers Anesthesia 9th edition page 1393

questions.text: What is the special use of the equipment given in the picture below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paediatric Intubation

 

Explanation:

 

This is Miller laryngoscope used for paediatric intubation.

 

  • It has a straight blade used for intubation in infants. This is required as epiglottis in infants is large and flexible.
  • It has a tongue which is straight with a slight curve near the tip.
  • In cross section, the flange, web, and tongue form a 'C' with the top flattened.
  • The side of the flange is reduced to minimize trauma and the curve at the beak or tip is extended to improve lifting of the epiglottis. These improvements facilitate easier intubation in paediatric patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Milers laryngoscope, is used for pediatric intubation. This equipment is designed with specific dimensions and features to accommodate the smaller anatomy of a child's airway, allowing for effective visualization of the larynx, and facilitating safe and successful intubation in pediatric patients.

 

Ref: Understanding Anaesthesia Equipment 5th edition page 148

choices.text: 3-4 cm Above Carina
3-4 cm Below the Carina
Below the Thyroid Cartilage
1-2 cm Above or Below the Carina

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is posted for exploratory laparotomy for bowel obstruction. Post-operatively the patient is electively ventilated in the ICU. An X-ray is done showing the position of the endotracheal tube. What is the ideal position to place the tip of the endotracheal tube?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 3-4 cm Above Carina

 

Option A. This is the correct placement for an endotracheal tube. It allows adequate ventilation of both lungs while minimizing the risk of accidental extubation or endobronchial intubation.

 

Explanation:

 

The ideal position for the endotracheal tube (ETT) tip is 3-4 cm above the carina to ensure proper ventilation and to avoid complications such as endobronchial intubation, which can occur if the tube is inserted too far.

 

Option B. 3-4 cm Below the Carina: Placement of the ETT this far below the carina would likely result in intubation of the right main bronchus due to its more vertical alignment, leading to overinflation of the right lung and collapse of the left lung.

 

Option C. Below the Thyroid Cartilage: This description is too vague, as the ETT tip could still be either too high or too low relative to the carina, and the thyroid cartilage is not a reliable landmark for correct ETT placement.

 

Option D. 1-2 cm Above or Below the Carina: While 1-2 cm above the carina might still be within the safe zone, 1-2 cm below the carina would be too low, risking mainstem bronchus intubation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The proximal tip of an endotracheal tube should be positioned at least 3-4 cm above the carina to ensure proper bilateral lung ventilation and to avoid the risk of one-lung ventilation or accidental extubation. Chest X-ray is the standard method for confirming appropriate ETT placement post-intubation.

 

 

Ref: Marinos the icu book 4th edition

choices.text: Laryngeal Mask Airway Insertion

questions.text: A patient with an intestinal obstruction secondary to TB of the ileum is posted for emergency surgery. What is the correct technique for securing a definitive airway during rapid sequence induction in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Orotracheal Intubation

 

Option B. This is the correct technique for securing a definitive airway. It involves placing an endotracheal tube through the mouth into the trachea, providing the highest level of protection against aspiration and allowing for controlled ventilation.

 

Explanation:

 

For a patient with intestinal obstruction secondary to tuberculosis of the ileum requiring emergency surgery, securing the airway is critical due to the increased risk of aspiration.

 

Option A. Oropharyngeal Airway: This is a device inserted into the mouth to keep the airway open, but it is not suitable for protecting against aspiration during anesthesia induction.

 

Option C. Laryngeal Mask Airway (LMA) Insertion: While an LMA can be a useful airway adjunct, it does not offer the same protection against aspiration as endotracheal intubation and is not considered a definitive airway.

 

Option D. Cricothyroidotomy: This is an emergency procedure to secure an airway when other methods are not possible. It is not the first-line option for a patient in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The definitive method for securing an airway in a patient with a high risk of aspiration, such as one with intestinal obstruction, is orotracheal intubation. This technique provides maximum protection against the aspiration of gastric contents and is the gold standard for airway management in emergency surgeries. Non-definitive airways like LMA, oropharyngeal, and nasopharyngeal airways do not offer adequate protection against aspiration for patients at risk.

 

 

Ref: Millers Anaesthesia 9th edition page 1392

choices.text: Long Length of Bronchi
Longer Length of Endotracheal Tube
Short Length of Trachea

questions.text: You intubate a 3-year-old child who is in stridor due to laryngotracheobronchitis. You can see chest rise only on the right side. On auscultation, air entry is absent on left side of the chest. What could be the reason for endobronchial intubation in children?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Short length of trachea

 

Option D. This is the correct answer. Children have a shorter trachea, and thus there is less distance from the vocal cords to the carina. This shorter distance makes it easier to inadvertently insert the ETT too far, leading to intubation of a mainstem bronchus, most commonly the right mainstem bronchus due to its more vertical alignment.

 

 

Explanation:

Endobronchial intubation occurs when the endotracheal tube (ETT) is inserted too far and passes beyond the carina into one of the mainstem bronchi. In children, the risk of endobronchial intubation is higher due to their anatomical differences compared to adults.

 

Option A. Long Length of Bronchi: This is not typically a risk factor for endobronchial intubation; in fact, adult bronchi are longer, which would make endobronchial intubation less likely if this were the sole factor.

 

Option B. Longer Length of Endotracheal Tube: While using an ETT that is too long can lead to endobronchial intubation, it is the depth of insertion, rather than the length of the tube itself, that typically causes the issue.

 

Option C. Floppy Epiglottis: A floppy epiglottis can make intubation more difficult, but it does not directly cause endobronchial intubation. It's more related to challenges in visualizing the vocal cords during the procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The short length of the trachea in children is a significant risk factor for endobronchial intubation, as it means there is less margin for error in the depth of ETT insertion before the tube passes the carina and enters a mainstem bronchus. This underscores the importance of careful ETT placement and confirmation of bilateral lung sounds after intubation in pediatric patients.

 

 

Ref: Gregory’s Paediatric Anaesthesia 6th edition

choices.text: Use of RAMP Position
Awake Fibreoptic Intubation

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with height 167 cm and weight 165 kg is posted for sleeve gastrectomy. What would you be careful to follow during induction of anaesthesia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Use of RAMP Position

 

Option A. This is the correct approach. The RAMP position, which aligns the patient’s tragus with the sternal notch, optimizes the airway alignment and visualization during intubation. It is particularly helpful in obese patients due to their unique anatomical challenges.

 

RAMP Position

 

 

Explanation:

 

Preoxygenation is mandatory in morbidly obese patients to prevent apnoea during laryngoscopy and intubation.

 

Option B. Awake Fibreoptic Intubation: This is an option for difficult airways or when standard laryngoscopy is anticipated to be challenging. However, it's not always necessary unless there are specific indications of a difficult airway beyond obesity.

 

Option C. Avoiding Preoxygenation: This would be incorrect. Preoxygenation is crucial in obese patients because they are at higher risk of rapid desaturation due to decreased functional residual capacity.

 

Option D. Deep Extubation: This would also be incorrect. Extubating a patient deeply anesthetized, especially if obese, increases the risk of airway obstruction and respiratory complications. These patients should be fully awake and responsive to ensure airway patency and adequate ventilation upon extubation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When inducing anesthesia in a morbidly obese patient, it is essential to employ the ramp position to align the ear and sternal notch, enhancing airway management. Preoxygenation is mandatory to prevent hypoxia, and patients should be fully awake before extubation to reduce the risk of airway complications.

 

 

Ref: Millers Anesthesia 9th edition page 1921-1924

questions.text: What is the concentration of viscous Lignocaine used for topical anaesthesia of oral cavity prior to awake Fibreoptic intubation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lignocaine 2%

 

Explanation:-

 

Lignocaine is used for preparation of airway in awake intubation. The oral cavity can be topicalized with a 2 percent lignocaine viscous solution that is swished around in the mouth for 5-10 minutes.

 

Lignocaine can also be applied to the mucosa with a 10% spray that comes in pressurised bottles (10 mg lignocaine per activation). Transtracheal injection can be given with Lignocaine 4%.

 

 

Ref: Ramkumar V. Preparation of the patient and the airway for awake intubation. Indian J Anaesth. 2011 Sep;55(5):442-7. doi: 10.4103/0019-5049.89863. PMID: 22174458; PMCID: PMC3237141.

choices.text: Equal to Minute Ventilation
1/2 the Minute Ventilation
2 times the Minute Ventilation
4 times the Minute Ventilation

questions.text: In Mapleson A circuit, what should the fresh gas flows be set at to prevent rebreathing?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Equal to Minute Ventilation.

 

Option A. This is correct. To prevent rebreathing in the Mapleson A circuit during spontaneous ventilation, the fresh gas flow should typically be set equal to the patient's minute ventilation. This ensures that expired gas is flushed out and does not mix with the fresh gas being inhaled.

 

  • Mapleson A or the Magill circuit is the circuit of choice for spontaneous ventilation.
  • In all Mapleson circuits, rebreathing of carbon dioxide is prevented by an adequate fresh gas flow and by the presence of adjustable pressure release valve. The exhaled carbon dioxide flows through the outer corrugated tube and out via this valve from where it can be scavenged.
  • Out of these, the Mapleson A circuit is considered the best for spontaneous ventilation because it requires a fresh gas inflow rate of only 1 times minute ventilation to prevent rebreathing of carbon dioxide.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. 1/2 the Minute Ventilation: This flow rate would be insufficient to prevent rebreathing in the Mapleson A circuit and could lead to the accumulation of carbon dioxide.

 

Option C. 2 times the Minute Ventilation: This would certainly prevent rebreathing, but it is more than necessary and would result in unnecessary waste of anesthetic gases and an increase in operating costs.

 

Option D. 4 times the Minute Ventilation: Similarly, this rate would prevent rebreathing, but it is excessively high and not cost-effective.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fresh gas flows in a Mapleson A circuit should be set equal to the patient’s minute ventilation to prevent rebreathing during spontaneous ventilation. This balance allows for the efficient removal of exhaled carbon dioxide while maintaining an adequate supply of fresh anesthetic gases.

 

 

Ref: Understanding Anaesthesia equipment 210-219

choices.text: Low Volume, Low Pressure
High Volume, High Pressure
Low Volume, High Pressure
High Volume, Low Pressure

questions.text: What is the type of cuff in the endotracheal tube given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. High Volume, Low Pressure

 

Explanation:

 

In most of the types of endotracheal tube there is a High-Volume, Low-Pressure cuff.

 

This is to prevent tracheal mucosal damage.

 

Endotracheal tubes with high pressure can cause problems like:

 

  • Sore throat
  • Aspiration
  • Difficulty in insertion of the tube

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

Ref: Millers Anesthesia 9th edition page 1392

questions.text: Which of these gases when used in general anaesthesia can diffuse into the cuff of the endotracheal tube and cause increase in cuff pressure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Nitrous Oxide

 

Explanation:

 

Nitrous Oxide has a High Solubility and Diffusivity, which means it, can readily diffuse into the air-filled spaces, including the cuff of an endotracheal tube, leading to an increase in pressure. Therefore, when nitrous oxide is used during anesthesia, the cuff pressure should be monitored and adjusted as necessary.

 

Thus, cuff pressure should be monitored periodically when nitrous oxide is used. The maximum cuff pressure that should be maintained is 25 cm of H2O. Excess cuff pressure can lead to tracheal mucosal injury and recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When using nitrous oxide in general anesthesia, it's important to monitor the cuff pressure of the endotracheal tube periodically because nitrous oxide can diffuse into the cuff, increasing the pressure which, if uncorrected, can lead to tracheal mucosal injury or recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy. The recommended maximum cuff pressure to maintain is around 25 cm H2O.

 

 

Ref: Miller's Anesthesia 9th edition Page no. 1392

choices.text: Diabetic Gastroparesis posted for Lap Cholecystectomy.
Trauma Patient posted for Emergency Surgery.
Fracture Mandible patient posted for Fracture Fixation.
Pregnant Patient posted for Emergency LSCS.

questions.text: In which of these situations is Bag and Mask ventilation not contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Fracture Mandible patient posted for Fracture Fixation.

 

Option C. If Airway Reflexes are Intact and there is No risk of Aspiration (such as a recent Meal, Gastrointestinal Obstruction, or Severe Gastroparesis), Bag and Mask Ventilation may not be contraindicated. It may be used carefully to oxygenate the patient before securing the airway, especially if the mandible fracture does not involve significant displacement that would affect the airway.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Diabetic Gastroparesis posted for Lap Cholecystectomy: This condition is associated with delayed gastric emptying, increasing the risk of aspiration during bag and mask ventilation, so it is generally contraindicated or used with extreme caution.

 

Option B. Trauma Patient posted for Emergency Surgery: In trauma patients, especially with an unknown time of last meal, the risk of aspiration is high, so bag and mask ventilation is typically avoided in favor of rapid sequence induction.

 

Option D. Pregnant Patient posted for Emergency LSCS: Pregnant patients, especially in the third trimester or in an emergency such as LSCS (Lower Segment Caesarean Section), have an increased risk of aspiration due to physiological changes and urgency of the situation. Therefore, bag and mask ventilation is usually avoided, and rapid sequence induction is preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In clinical practice, bag and mask ventilation should be used with caution, considering the risk of aspiration. It is generally contraindicated in situations where the stomach content might enter the lungs, such as in patients with full stomachs, intestinal obstruction, pregnancy, or conditions like diabetic gastroparesis. In the case of a fracture mandible where there is no significant risk of aspiration, bag and mask ventilation may be safely utilized if necessary.

 

 

Ref: Miller's Anesthesia 9th edition Page no. 1392

choices.text: Both of the above
None of the above

questions.text: Which of these muscle relaxants is preferred for Rapid Sequence Induction (RSI)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Both of the above

 

Explanation:

 

Succinylcholine is the depolarising muscle relaxant of choice for RSI since it has a rapid onset and short duration of action.

 

Rocuronium is the non-depolarising muscle relaxant of choice for RSI, used when succinylcholine is contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective 

Both succinylcholine, a depolarizing agent, and rocuronium, a non-depolarizing agent, are appropriate muscle relaxants for RSI

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Anaesthesiology, 5th edition page 291

questions.text: Identify the instruments given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Airway Cart

 

Option B. This is the correct answer. An airway cart is equipped with various sizes of laryngoscope blades, endotracheal tubes, masks, laryngeal mask airways, and possibly also advanced equipment like flexible fiberoptic intubation tools. The cart in the image is consistent with the equipment one would expect in an airway cart.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Crash Cart: A crash cart contains emergency medical supplies and medication that are used in cardiac arrest.

 

Option C. Operating Room Cart: While an operating room cart may contain a variety of surgical instruments and supplies, the specific collection of airway equipment seen here is more specialized than what would be found in a general operating room cart.

 

Option D. Intubation Cart: An intubation cart would contain equipment specifically for intubation, and while this could be another name for an airway cart, the term "airway cart" is more inclusive, covering a broader range of airway management tools, not just those for intubation.

 

Educational objective:

 

Components of an Airway Cart:

 

  • Laryngoscope blades of various sizes
  • Tracheal tubes of various sizes.
  • Masks of various sizes.
  • Laryngeal mask airways of various sizes.
  • Flexible Fibreoptic intubation equipment.
  • Retrograde intubation equipment.
  • Oropharyngeal and Nasopharyngeal airways
  • Emergency non-invasive airway ventilation equipment
  • Capnometer

 

 

Ref: https://www.google.com/url?sa=i&url=https%3A%2F%2Fprehospitalmed.com%2F2013%2F02%2F20%2Fairway-trolley-design%2F&psig=AOvVaw0_OrkxoTGkrYrJZwpw5kSa&ust=1672423114594000&source=images&cd=vfe&ved=0CBEQjhxqFwoTCJDmid6zn_wCFQAAAAAdAAAAABAR

choices.text: Increased Peak Airway Pressures
Increased Plateau Pressure
Fall in Oxygen Saturation
All of the above are Signs of Endobronchial Intubation

questions.text: Which of these is not a sign of Endobronchial intubation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Increased Plateau Pressure
