Option B. Plateau pressure reflects the pressure in the lungs at the end of inspiration when there is no air movement. It is not typically affected by endobronchial intubation alone, as this would primarily increase peak pressures related to airflow resistance rather than alveolar pressures.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Increased Peak Airway Pressures: This can occur with endobronchial intubation due to the increased resistance from only one lung being ventilated, and the other lung potentially collapsing or receiving less ventilation.

 

Option C. Fall in Oxygen Saturation: If the tube is placed in the right mainstem bronchus, the left lung may not be ventilated, which can lead to a fall in oxygen saturation due to reduced gas exchange.

 

Option D. All of the above are signs of Endobronchial Intubation: This is incorrect because, as explained, increased plateau pressure is not a sign of endobronchial intubation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Signs of Endobronchial Intubation:

 

  • Increased peak inspiratory pressure
  • Asymmetric chest expansion
  • Unilateral breath sounds on auscultation
  • Hypoxemia

 

Increase in plateau pressure is seen in:

 

  • Use of high PEEP, inspiratory flow, and tidal volume

 

 

Ref: Miller's Anesthesia 9th edition Page no. 1397

choices.text: Face Mask with Reservoir

questions.text: In an anaesthesia viva voce exam, the third-year resident is asked to pick a fixed performance oxygen therapy device from the various oxygen therapy devices kept on the table. Which one should he pick up?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Venturi Mask

 

Explanation:

 

Oxygen Therapy Devices
 

  • Supplemental Oxygen can be supplied by a variety of devices.

 

The devices can be classified into two types:

 

Classification of oxygen therapy devices:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

For precise oxygen therapy where a specific oxygen concentration is required, a Venturi mask is the appropriate fixed performance device to use. It employs a mechanism based on the Venturi effect to mix room air and pure oxygen in a controlled manner, providing a consistent and known oxygen concentration to the patient.

 

 

Ref: Understanding Anesthetic Equipment and Procedures, Dwarkadas K Baheti pg 234

questions.text: Identify this oxygen therapy device?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Tracheostomy Mask

 

Option D. This is the correct answer. A tracheostomy mask fits over the stoma (opening) of a tracheostomy to deliver oxygen directly to the trachea.

 

This is a tracheostomy mask that looks like a simple face mask used at tracheostomy site.

 

It is used in patients with permanent or temporary tracheostomy or stoma in patients who underwent total laryngectomy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Oxygen Hood: This is typically used for infants and encloses their heads to provide them with oxygen.

 

Option B. Venturi Mask: This mask delivers a precise concentration of oxygen and uses a mechanism based on the Venturi effect.

 

Option C. Face Mask: A standard face mask covers the patient's nose and mouth but is not specifically designed for use with a tracheostomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A tracheostomy mask is designed to fit over a tracheostomy stoma and deliver oxygen therapy to patients who either have a permanent tracheostomy or a temporary one, such as after laryngectomy. It is essential to ensure an adequate flow rate, usually 3–4 L/minute, to prevent the rebreathing of expired gas and the accumulation of carbon dioxide, which can lead to drowsiness or other complications. The delivered fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) can vary depending on several factors including the patient's breathing pattern and the fit of the mask.

 

 

Ref: Understanding Anesthetic Equipment and Procedures, Dwarkadas K Baheti pg 235

questions.text: A patient with COPD comes in acute respiratory distress with spo2-90% on room air. You attach a venturi mask to this patient to give controlled oxygen concentration. What is the maximum O2 concentration attained in a venturi mask?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 60%

 

Explanation:

 

Ventimask or venturi masks are high flow or fixed performance (performance not affected by changes in patient's tidal volume and respiratory rate) oxygen delivery devices delivering accurate oxygen concentration (maximum up to 60%).

 

A Venturi is a simple design of valve that uses high-flow oxygen supplied through a narrow port which allows room air to be drawn in from atmosphere (Venturi principle). The rate of flow generated by this Venturi principle and Venturi mask may be equal to peak inspiratory flow of patient. There are different coloured dilutor jets which deliver a particular FiO2 (2450% depending upon the use of dilutor jet) at a particular flow rate set and marked or embossed onto bottom of the dilutor. It is most commonly used for Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) patients requiring a specific FiO2 that will not fluctuate with changes in breathing pattern.

 

 

Flow rate and FiO2 with Venturi Mask

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Venturi mask is beneficial for patients who require a specific and controlled concentration of oxygen, such as those with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). For these patients, delivering too high a concentration of oxygen can suppress their respiratory drive. The maximum oxygen concentration attainable with a Venturi mask is typically about 60%.

 

 

Ref: Understanding Anesthetic Equipment and Procedures, Dwarkadas K Baheti pg 236

choices.text: Non Rebreathing Mask
Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP)

questions.text: Which one of these is a low flow oxygen therapy device?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Non rebreathing mask

 

Explanation:

 

Educational Objective 

Non-rebreathing mask is classified as a low-flow oxygen therapy device.

 

Ref: Understanding Anesthetic Equipment and Procedures, Dwarkadas K Baheti pg 234

questions.text: Identify the maximum FiO2 (Fraction of Inspired Oxygen) given by the device shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 80%

 

Explanation:

 

The device shown in the image is a Non-Rebreathing Mask.

 

The non-rebreathing mask typically consists of a face mask with an attached oxygen reservoir bag that is connected to an oxygen source. It has a series of one-way valves to prevent exhaled gas from returning to the bag and diluting the oxygen concentration. When set up properly and with a sufficient flow rate of oxygen (usually around 10 to 15 liters per minute), this system can deliver high concentrations of oxygen, typically up to 80% FiO2 or higher.

 

It is designed for patients who require short- term high concentrations of oxygen. The FiO2 depends on the flow rate, at 15 L/minute of flow rate FiO2 is about 90%; whereas at 10 L/minute of flow rate, FiO2 is almost 80%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A non-rebreathing mask can deliver a high FiO2, typically up to around 80% at a flow rate of 10 L/min, and close to 90% at a flow rate of 15 L/min. This device is used for delivering high concentrations of oxygen in acute and emergent conditions and is suitable for short-term use due to the potential for complications with prolonged use of dry gases.

 

 

Ref: Understanding Anesthetic Equipment and Procedures, Dwarkadas K Baheti pg 237
